text:
The army should be able to
talk loud enough, right. And, actually,
China, we can see it

competing with the
United States and the West with a whole government
approach, trying to prevail,

trying to be a regional
if not global power. So things didn't go
how we wanted it. So we had to say,
hey, we had to treat

China and Russia for who they
are, not who we want them to be. We wrote a national
security strategy that acknowledged that we are
in great power competition

with our strategic rivals. We need to cooperate where we
can, but compete where we must. And the last administration
embraced this.

I'm an international
relations guy. For those of you know that
national interests are enduring and it shouldn't be politicized,
so the current administration's

national security strategy,
national defense strategy, more similarities
than difference. There's a recognition that
China is a pacing threat,

that we are in great
power competition. Now, the Cold War, we prevailed. Where was the technology
that helped us prevail

in the Cold War coming from? Big government labs,
big defense primes.

And if we built an
incrementally better large end systems like aircraft carriers,
submarines, fighter jets

every 10 years, we could stay
ahead of the Soviets and win. And we did. The problem is, where
is the technology

that we need to
compete and prevail in today's competition,
not just the military, but across all of
government, coming from?

The commercial sector. You think about the technology--
you guys are familiar with-- and we're going to hear about
this course, AI autonomy, cyber,

those types of
technologies, and where developments and advancements. Back in the day in the Cold
War, technology advances

were driven by
government directives. They said, it's
improved this technology so we can build a
better logging system.

Now it's coming from the
commercial sector driven by-- an advanced are being
driven by consumer demand,

not government directed. So that's changed everything. So to be effective, we need
to be able to identify, adopt, and deploy those
technologies coming out

of the commercial sector
at speed and scale, or we're going to lose. And that's not
going to be pretty. So Silicon Valley
and the government

have to be closer
than ever before. And you're going to hear
from a great range of number of speakers in
this course who are

kind of working in that
nexus between Silicon Valley technology and the
government because we want

to win this competition too. All right, the vision that
we have for the future, we're a rules-based
order is going to endure.

It's a vision that's
not just America shares, but it's shared, embraced by so
many of our allies and partners around the world.

And I'd say it's in the bounds. It's going to be determined
here in the next 10 years if we're going to prevail-- if that vision for
future prevails

or the alternative vision that-- which is very
different, prevails. So it's an important class
and important topics,

great speakers. And thanks, again, Ernestine
and Paul for the chance to join. And over to you, Paul,
to introduce some folks

but thanks for being here. Thanks for having us. So I'm Paul Kwan from
General Catalyst. Excited to have one
of our portfolio

companies, Applied Intuition,
kick us off for this semester. Qasar Younis, CEO, co-founder
of Applied Intuition.
Thanks for coming by. Thanks for having me. Does this mic work? Hi. Is this on? Can you hear it?

Yes, it does, yeah. Set the bar high. We have a-- Or low. Or low, a quote from my
partner Hemant Taneja,

who you've known for a while. Why is Applied Intuition
so interesting? It's a tier one
software supplier

transforming the auto industry. This is, in Hemant's words, "The
only founder that's been able

to do a complex enterprise
software company to transform an industry with high growth
and high profitability."

We've just never seen
that in our history. So we'll just jump
right into it. Very flattering. Yeah.

Walk us through, real quick,
Pakistani-American, grew up in Detroit, went to General
Motors Institute, now

Kettering University. Why autos? That background
growing up as a kid.

Yeah. I think if you ever grew
up in an industry town-- and the Bay Area is kind
of an industry town.

Industry towns where
everyone's making money from the same thing. You go to Houston or
something like this,

you fall into the industry
kind of as a default. We're immigrants. My parents were uneducated. So if you're strong
at science and math,

you're going to go to
U of M, that's kind of the best of the Midwest. I mean, that's
even a pejorative.

It's a great school, but that's
kind of the horizon, University of Michigan, Ann Arbor.

And I kind of-- I don't know if some of
you had this feeling, but when you're in
high school, there's

a little bit of a
resentment, especially if you're not in the inside. And for me, that ultimately
led to like, man,

am I just going to be another
one of these Ann Arbor kids? And GMI-- as it was known
when I went to the school--

the school changed its name
to Kettering University-- is a very unique school. The rule of the shorthand is
the West Point of automotive.

It's a small, private
engineering school, very much-- it started
by General Motors 100 years ago when there
were not enough engineers.

And GM said, well, what better
thing to do than just produce our own engineers. And the school
still exists today.

What's unique about it--
if you guys know Waterloo, you work half the time, you
go to school half the time. So you have to have
a corporate sponsor.

And that's not--
that's a requirement. So you have to start
interviewing right when

you get out of high school. And if you don't get a job,
you don't go to school. Like it's a requirement.

And so you have to be a
particular type of person who's like, I want to work
in corporations, I want to be an
engineer, and I don't

mind living in Flint, Michigan,
which is not Stanford. That's the most
polite way to say. As we walk through
this really nice campus

and like birds chirping, I
was like, this is not Flint, Michigan. And so I ended up there
because I didn't want

to do the mainstream thing. And I do love the car business,
still love the car business, still love the
car business here. And the way that it's related to
defense is, if you don't know,

the car business and the
defense are kind of primes. They're like cousins.

They're very similar
types of engineers. They build vehicles,
a lot of them are based in Detroit, Michigan,
TACOM, and General Dynamics Land

Systems, and BA. All these companies are
in Southeast Michigan with large tech centers. And so very much grew
up in the show room.

And TACOM was right
outside of my neighborhood. I mean I think one of the things
we've come away with today

is kind of how Applied Intuition
has transformed the auto industry with software, and
then increasingly the defense

industry-- we'll come
back to that as well. We'll also talk about
the incredible career you had at Y Combinator.

So along the way you became
a GP and CEO at Y Combinator. And I think for you
all in the audience,

it's an incredible privilege
to have Qasar here. He's probably one of the
most sought after founders,

startup advisors
out there, bar none, and so we'll go through
some of that as well. But before we get to
all that, let's go back.

You're in college,
right after college, what do you think you
would have told yourself then knowing what you know now?

Let me-- so, I
mean, there's a lot. But I would say--
let me just shorten

it to compress it to
the two or three things I think that were correct. A lot of things I would
have told you that probably

were wrong. Correct is you have to figure
out your long term trajectory.

So if your undergrads, early
20s, you graduate at 21, 22,

and you have essentially like
two or three paths in front of you. One path is grad school.

The second path
is go work at a-- I'm talking hyper local here. So this is not like--

if you're in India or you're
somewhere around the world, that's going to
be very different. I know this is
recorded, but this is for like Stanford students. One path is startups and then
one path is large companies.

And then it's like, where does
VC in all this stuff fall into? So maybe let's use a
framework which is a spectrum.

And I kind of always think
of everything on a spectrum. On one end you have being
a founder and the other end

you have working,
let's say, at the DOD. And so you can put every
type of job on this spectrum.

And so what I'm really
saying is in one end you have essentially the
unknown kind of path,

which is the path you
have to create yourself. And the other is
there's an institution. And you're going to
join that institution,

and the institution
is going to teach you how to be a professional or
whatever the occupation that you choose.

And so now you have to figure
out-- the next thing you figure out is, OK, am I on
the disruption side

or am I on the
institutional side? There's pros and cons of both. On the institution side,
the pro is just like

you're at Stanford-- and I said
this at Harvard last week-- you came to Stanford--
and don't fool yourself,

part of the reason you came to
Stanford is there's a brand. It's an institution. You're learning from this--

from the professors and
the other students here. And when you walk out with
that hoodie that says Stanford,

you represent-- it's like
being in the military. It's a very established
rank and order. And that works.

What are the downsides of
that part of the spectrum? The downsides of that part of
the spectrum is frustration.

If you go join a large
corporation like General Motors or Google or an established
house like McKinsey or Goldman

or whatever, Kleiner
Perkins, you're just a cog in that system. And that's the intention.

You're going to learn,
but you don't really have a lot of
provenance, you don't have a lot of determination
to what you're going to do.

On the far end of that
spectrum is you can say, you know what, I hate
all those things. I was never a-- I'm going to be in
the rebel battalion.

And I get no uniform,
I get nothing, I get no training, nothing,
but I fight the fight that I want to fight.

So what are the-- that
sounds very appealing. Well, why doesn't
everybody do that? Or the downside of
that is you pay with--

instead of frustration,
you pay with fear because you have no idea
what the future holds. And you could spend your
time doing a startup

or whatever that
thing on your own is, and then find out after
five or eight years that you learned very little and
you have very little to show.

And that's actually a very
disadvantaged position because all the people
who are on the other side of the spectrum,
they've accrued skills.

And so when you're 30 now, as
you compare each other to look at the similar opportunities,
that could be financing,

literally could be getting
money for your company, actually, that person
might be more attractive. And so this is the kind
of multivariate problem

that you have to figure
out, which is like, what am I good at? What's the risk I'm
willing to take? What is my financial situation?

What can I what can I eat? And for me, I always
thought that I

was on the rebel battalion
because I was poor, and it was a-- startups and starting a
company is a non-linear way

to grow wealth. It was an extremely
pragmatic reason why I entered
startups, nothing else.

In Detroit and Michigan, there
isn't a whole startup ecosystem. So for me it was a very,
like cold, methodical,

this is how I don't
become an employee. I used to work at-- my first job was McDonald's. And I said this at Google-- I worked at Google for a
bunch of years-- and I said,

there isn't much
of a big difference between a McDonald's employee
and a Google's employee. The McDonald's employee
and the Google employee both wore uniforms.

We all have uniforms, we're
all wearing a certain type of clothes that our peers
will accept and deem to be appropriate for the
function that we are assigned.

And if you're a software
engineer at Google, there is something that
falls within that realm. And both people put in
orders into a computer.

McDonald's and Google, there's
not that big of a difference, but we imply there's a
lot big of a difference.

And so I think for me, I
always thought that's almost-- I was allergic to that.

And I also have a weird name
and maybe all the insecurities you have as an immigrant.

And so very much I thought I
did this for wealth accumulation and for the system
might not accept me.

As I worked-- and I've
worked in big companies-- five years of General
Motors, two years at Bosch, two years at Sears, three
and 1/2 years at Google.

So over a decade
in large companies, over 100,000 employees. And when I was at UIC,
my most recent thing,

I had kind of surpassed all the
things that as a 22-year-old that you want. A 22 you're wondering
all these things,

and you get family and all this. And now I'm checked
all those things off and I realized I still
wanted to do a startup.

And I think fundamentally,
it wasn't actually money and it wasn't
anything other than I

function the best in this
part of the spectrum. And it took me 20
years to figure out. So you have to
figure out, ideally,

in less than 20 years, what part
of the spectrum that you fall and then you optimize
your skills based on that.

I think that was
incredible advice there Qasar, kind of compressing all
that into those sound bites.

The Google versus McDonald's,
I'll never forget that. Sorry to my Google peers
who are watching this.

You're at UIC helping run that. You're, obviously, the
preeminent tech startup

accelerator. What are some of the
non-obvious things about starting a
company, for those who want to go on the founder
journey, that are not obvious?

You talk about this linear
checklist progression, let's just share
some of that wisdom because, again,
that's having seen

all those cohorts at YC,
all those founders, all the missteps. Kind of break that down for us. Yeah, let me talk
about the mode that I

think most Stanford students do
trying to apply to YC fall into.

And it's the brand train. Sam Altman talked about it,
Paul Graham's talked about it.

And the brand train
is you went to Andover or you went to Phillips
Exeter or TJ or something

like this because of either
your raw intelligence or your parents' ability to help
you put you on the right path.

You can do a place like
Stanford or Harvard or wherever, but Stanford in this case. And then from there, the
next brand after is Google,

or it might be McKinsey
or Bain, whatever thing you want to go to. Then you might go to grad school
or you might go to Y Combinator.

Y Combinator has just
become another train on the brand train. And you see these
founders who show up, and they actually don't care
about starting a company.

And the best evidence of
that is like the equivalent-- That founder vibe. So Trey Stevens last semester,
looking for founder vibes.
Yeah, yeah, exactly. Or like the-- it's like the--

it's any time that
you're enamored with the superficiality
of the thing without understanding
the cost of the thing,

whether you go in the
military because there's an emotional response
but you actually don't understand the
mission that is actually the underlying
reason why you should

do what you're trying to do. And so people end
up in the YC bucket we'd often see because it's
just the next brand thing to do,

because it's what-- and for everybody, but
especially people in this room,

you are heavily influenced
by your peers to a degree that even if you say, I'm
not, I'm going to push back,

you are a product of your peers. If we were in some
school in Cambodia,

we wouldn't be having this
conversation about startups. We'd be having a conversation
about something very, very different. That's the evidence.

So the first most important
question is, why startups? So once you're past that,
YC is a fantastic on-ramp

because YC does what other funds
have always struggled to do, which is look at people
who are not vetted.

You're vetted in some
way, you're in network. You can probably go
to Ann at Floodgate. She teaches a class here.

Paul is a-- top tier VCs
are available to you, but for most people on the
planet, they don't have that.

And YC is a fantastic
on-ramp to that. And that's the innovation that
YC has and anybody can apply.

Now, I would say
the obvious things that YC does that has
been talked about a lot so I won't go over
the same thing, which

is it helps you focus, it
gets you ready for demo day, it creates a pressure, all those
things are absolutely correct. It's extremely valuable.

The things that I think now that
I've done this company for seven years that are kind
of counterintuitive

is one is total underestimation
of your ability and requirement

to recruit people. So many YC founders
can raise that money or even get a co-founder,
but they have no idea

how to consistently recruit. So recruiting isn't
just a convince Daniel

to come join my company. That's not recruit. Recruiting is
understanding what we're good at, what we need-- what
we're weak at, what we need

to build, what your skills are,
where you are in your life, what experiences that you have.

Are you going to be
the right next person on this hyper specialized team? A company, again, like an
institution at a Google,

you just want bodies. You're looking for humans
to fill butts and seats.

On the other end of the spectrum
and the rebel battalion, you have to have a very--
because there's only two or three seats available.

Just like the skills
you want to get out and who can do those
skills as opposed to who's a friend of a friend or
who's down the hallway.

Yeah. But the reality
of the situation, sometimes you only have
the friend of the friend because you are one of
hundreds of startups at YC

and one of thousands
in the Bay Area and all pitching the same thing. We raised $3 million from
all these great investors,

come join us as
an early employee. So the requirement
for recruiting or the need for having a
strong recruiting muscle

is something I didn't appreciate
when I was doing my YC company, when I was an employee at YC.

And then in terms of I would
say number two on the list is the well-roundedness
requirement of founders.

So, I think, a lot of
us are being engineers, a lot of us being
technical, we very much emphasize the ability
to be technical,

but people don't talk
enough about the ability to actually grow. When you're starting
a company, you're the chief executive officer.

So you need to know the
marketing function as well as your head of
marketing, you need to know the people function,
you need to know sales,

you need to know operations,
you need to know engineering, you need to know product,
you need to know design. There's a dozen functions
that you really need to know.

And when you're 22, hint,
you don't know any of them. Maybe not even one.

And now you're going to
go try to recruit somebody to be your head of people,
and they look at you and they're like,
you don't know-- you don't know how
to spell HR let alone

build a function of HR. And that, by the way,
goes all the way down. Engineering is
especially difficult.

Situation where there's a
very well known YC company-- I won't say the name--
worth more than $5 billion.

Very young founder, comes from
a school as great as Stanford, was a dropout. And he asked me,
how do you apply--

how do you guys recruit
such senior people? And I said to the
person, well, part of it is I'm not 23 years old.

And the reality is
there's people like you who are 38 years old who've been
writing software for 15 years.

And if you're 23 and you're
trying to recruit them, good luck. It's going to be really,
really difficult. So experience and
well-roundedness, the ability

and that the second that
translates to recruiting, but it itself is
like its own skill.

The medium founder,
by the way, YC is 30, so half of the
founders are above that. I think if you look
at the top startups,

with the exception of,
I would say, Stripe-- those guys are older
now, but Stripe when they started
and scale, I think

everyone is like a fairly-- I would-- the nice way
to say old is mature-- everyone's a mature founder.

And so you, if you really
want to be a founder, I think it's not how do
I get on the brand train,

it really is how do I build
up the capabilities that I can

execute and build a company? And I think that
really is the focus. Yeah, there's a lot
of great content.

I'm good. I think you also talked about
the Paul Graham 18 Mistakes Founders Make.

You can look that
up, a 2006 blog. Definitely worth reading. You'll get that, I
think, every few months. So let's fast forward
to Applied Intuition.

Kind of like maybe
just for the audience, like, the size and scope of
this business and the speed

by which you've built it just to
level set for people like what you're doing and to
understand the totality of it,

first and foremost. Yeah, I'll assume nobody
here knows Applied. If you do, I apologize
for the rehash here.

So fundamentally we're
a software company. And we build-- if you take
the Venn diagram of vehicles

and software, what's
in the middle of that is what we work on. We originally started the
company just focused on tools.

And those tools
were specifically to build autonomous systems. And we conquered that
market pretty well.

I think there's not
much debate if we're the market leader there. From there we expanded to all
software testing on vehicles.

So if you're writing
a web app or you're writing a mobile app, how
you test the mobile app is maybe test flight or web
app on your local browser.

If you're deploying
software to a vehicle-- and that can be from a
sports car to a tank-- there isn't a web
browser you test it in.

And we build the tools
that allow you to do that. And it's a whole host
of tools to do that. That's one business line.

The second business line
we recently announced which was private
for many years, was it's a vehicle platform.

So it's a onboard software
that sits basically between silicon and
the application that

sit on a vehicle,
off board software, the development environment
in order to control and things do like OTA and vehicle logs, et
cetera, and then the developer

experience beyond that. And so that's a vehicle
platform business. That's our second pillar.

and that is off road autonomy. So you're trying to-- if you've
heard of things like the robot

combat vehicle program or XM 30,
that's the area that we play in. Within autonomy--
within defense, broadly,

but within the autonomy
verticals specifically, we supply the existing primes--
like the General Dynamics

and General Atomics
and those folks-- to the new primes. Anduril is a customer all
the way to the DOD directly

and all the sub-groups
that DIU and F works. And so we're really a supplier
across the full spectrum.

And, I think, just to juxtapose
like an Anduril as an example. And Anduril, because
you guys have-- you guys probably know the
company, they very much

position themselves
as a new prime, almost like a antagonist
to the existing order.

And the existing order being
the five kind of dominant primes in the business. We're actually very different. We're a horizontal company.

We supply everybody. So our view is to-- and mission of the
company is to accelerate

the deployment of safe
and intelligent machines. And so those machines are
safe, intelligent machines, can be passenger vehicles and
they can be commercial trucks

and they can be dirt movers
from construction or mining or agriculture, all the
way to defense vehicles.

So, yeah, that's what we do. I don't know if there's
a real comp of us in the industry in each of the
verticals-- like in the tooling

comps, it's like if
you guys know Ansys. If you're any mechanical
engineers or if you're-- if you're cadence or
synopsis, that's kind of that.

In the vehicle
platforms, I guess NVIDIA saying this is
interesting being in the NVIDIA. Software Bosch where we work.

The software Bosch. The iOS for
transportation of assets.

Could I maybe just jump to
the billion dollar question. And the thing, we
talk about GC is

how you've been able to
engage on the autos business. 18 of the top 20
OEMs, these are people

who don't move very quickly,
have incredibly high technical bars. Maybe talk about the Porsche
announcement, which is obviously

a humongous outcome here. How did you transform-- get into these customers and
help modernize and transform

them in just a few, three
years plus time frame? Yeah, I'll use the
General Dynamics example

because it's public. And I think it's a
good illustration. GD came here to an EBC locally.

And we met them. General Land Systems is
like 70% of the land market.

They're the prime that
does tanks, basically, and troop movers. And they wanted to use our
tools to build autonomy systems.

And after engaging with
us, they ultimately said, can you actually help
us build the autonomy stack as a reference stack?

And so how do you go from
the first conversation to, let's say, five
year relationship

where you're working in a very,
very complex and integrated way? The fundamental truth is slowly
and in a very precise way.

When you're working
with large enterprises, you have to have extreme EQ in
the sense of the organization.

You as an Applied
Intuition has to have understand what are
the customer needs and how do you deliver
what the customer needs,

while at the same
time recognizing we're not an engineering
services company, we're not an NRE shop.

We don't build stuff and
then we just sell our ours. So you have to squint
and figure out,

what can I build
with this customer that will also be relevant
to other companies that

are like this? And are there other
companies like this? If there are not other
companies like this, you have to think long
and hard, do I actually

want to do this business? so I think for us, with
all vehicle manufacturers, they're all very good at
manufacturing vehicles.

So whether it's
commercial vehicles, whether it's cars or tanks. What they're not
good at is software.

And that's where we-- I think that's where the
combination is very, very-- Let's just talk about
the technical complexity

of what we build
for our customers, we have to get it right. Obviously, we hire a
great technologists,

we have the great
culture, but let's just understand when
you're building things that have to be 101% accurate,
how do we actually do that?

Well, I mean, I think the things
that we just quickly ran over are important, culture
and who you hire.

I think it's in safety systems. This is the beginning,
middle, and end. And so we work on, obviously,
mission critical safety systems.

So from the beginning
of the company-- I've done a bunch
of talks on YouTube so I won't rehash how we run
the innards of the company

but what you're really-- Paul is really getting at is,
what are the functions that run the company?

And in many, many
ways I think we've been extremely intentional
about how we build inside

of the company. Part of this is
my third company. That's a part of it. Part of is I saw the things
that were incorrectly

done at Google and at General
Motors and other places, and it's a reflection to that. And part of it is that's how
you run complex engagements.

You have to be hyper
organized and you have to incentivize the team
to do the right behaviors.

So just a very
quick peek into what that means in a
tactical level and I think what's worked
really well for us.

When our company was
about 10 employees, we wrote out, essentially, what
become our operating principles.

We call them our values. But where most companies kind
of falter on that is they never close the loop.

So they write these things
and they're kind outside of the day to day work. And so what is the
day to day work?

Well, the day to
day work is not only success in terms of the
revenue, multiple or revenue growth of the company, it's
also compensation and promotion

and literally what you
celebrate at all hands. And so all of that
stuff is infused, all the values are
infused in the day to day.

It's all the way
from recruiting. Recruiting it applied,
we are judging you against the adherence
of our values. That's the simple
fundamental truth.

When you're in the company, if
you are working on a project or success of a project,
whether it's going well or not,

it is around the adherence of
the values, and then all the way to getting promoted
and moving up. So I think it's just like
there's a bunch of it.

So we recruit from three
schools exclusively, Stanford, MIT and Berkeley. We found the right
mix of startup people

and technical depth. If there's people, for
sure, you know in this room

that work at Applied. You can just ask them,
have a lunch or dinner. Say like, why does
a company do well? And it's a very,
very nuanced answer.

It's not like we just
had lunch paid for. Like, that's not what
makes a great company. And maybe another way
to think about this

is if you're into
sports or anything, what makes a dynasty, what
